Posts.Content: Originally Posted by WifeinWorry Would there be any reason why a PSA blood work results be different from one lab than the other? curious... WifeinWorry, Different labs use different "assays"; which is a fancy term for how they measure the PSA, and what is the lower limit of their equipment. The old standard assay only measured as low as 0.1. Anything under that was considered undetectable. Then they came out with a more sensitive assay (which mine is) that measures down to 0.06. Anything below that was considered undetectable. Then they came out with the ultra-sensitive assay; which can measure down to 0.01. If your lab uses a particular assay, and then you switch to another lab which uses a different assay, you cannot be sure that you are measuring apples to apples. The underlying method of measuring the PSA could actually be different between assays. If you do switch to another lab which uses a different assay; they suggest 3 PSA tests with the new one before you can be sure that the measurements are accurate. Hope that helps, Bob

You are only allowed a certain number of characters, so keep it concise. I can't remember how many characters; but usually you can get in the important info. -Bob

Posts.Title: Where do you post your path reports so that they come up on the page when you post?

Posts.Content: Hello. In regards to your question, I did find this site: http://meetinglibrary.asco.org/content/129472-144 which is an Abstract dealing with ASAP, which was presented at a Prostate Cancer annual meeting. Here is the relevant information: Conclusions: Our results demonstrate that a limited number of patients (37.5%) with an initial diagnosis of ASAP went on to develop prostate cancer if they had a repeat biopsy within 2.5 years. Of the 37.5% who progressed, 76.3% developed low risk prostate cancer defined by Damico criteria. Significantly, no patients developed high risk disease following an initial diagnosis of ASAP. Based on this information we recommend that an ASAP diagnosis be managed with active surveillance. This would include PSA and DRE at 4-6 month intervals followed by a repeat biopsy at one year. So, it sounds like there is a low possibility (just over one third of patients) indicating a chance of low-risk PCa, and a very slight indicator of medium-risk PCa. So, your uro's recommendation sounds reasonable. Hopefully, you will stay out of The Club. -Bob

Posts.Title: Biopsy ASAP Result Questions

Posts.Content: Gabka, Hopefully, my experience can help to give you some good news. My biopsy also showed a Gleason 7(3+4); but my final pathology showed a Gleason 8(4+4). And mine didn't just show the cancer pushing against the wall; it had broken out. But my surgeon was aggressive in his cutting, and I had negative surgical margins - that is a good thing. That was 2 years ago next week. So, even with worse final numbers than your hubby, I have gone 2 years in the Zero Club. No PSA has been detected. I still get a PSA test every 4 months, because of my numbers; but it has become much less stressful than the first year. So hang on to your hope. There is life after surgery, even if the final pathology turned out worse than you expected it to. Keep us posted, and I agree that more info from the final pathology report would be helpful. -Bob

Posts.Title: My husbands prostete cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by masbirdies Thanks everyone! I feel well prepared now. Results tomorrow, I'll be sure to report the findings masbirdies, Look at the pathology report very closely. And remember that there are no dumb questions! If you don't understand a term, ask! I second the idea of getting a copy of the report, if they don't give you one. It took me a couple of reads, after I got home, before I noticed the terms "extensive perineural and angiolymphatic invasion identified". I knew what perineural invasion was; but I had no clue what angiolymphatic invasion meant. FYI, it means that they found cancer cells in the blood vessels of the prostate; which means it had ample opportunity to get out; hence my rising PSA 3 years later. The next visit I asked my uro what that meant, and he enlightened me. That brings up another point; don't think that you can only ask questions at the time he goes over it. If you are looking at it later, and you have a question, ask it at your next visit. If your uro is like mine, he is glad to answer any questions. But if I don't ask, he has no way of knowing that I don't understand something. Good luck on the report! -Bob

Posts.Title: Questions to ask surgeon at pathology report

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by WifeinWorry How can you identify bone pain without a bone scan? Could it be just muscle pain? WifeinWorry, At my visit to the medical oncologist 2 weeks ago, he asked if I was feeling any pain in my bones. He said that pain from bone mets is more of a dull pain, rather than a sharp pain. He also said that it tends to be there all; or most of; the time. Thankfully, I have not had to experience it yet. Perhaps some of the guys who are dealing with it will chime in. -Bob

Posts.Title: Bone pain due to Prostate Cancer (M)

Posts.Content: Hello Dshinnick, Other than that little bit of G7(3+4), it looks like a very good path report. I think the "one possible lymph node" comment comes from the nature of lymph nodes. As my doctor explained it to me, lymph nodes are not these easily identifiable discrete objects. They are not always easy to identify from surrounding tissue. The pathologist uses that kind of terminology to basically CYA. They assume that it is a lymph node, because that's what it was labelled as when removed. They examine the tissue and look for any cancer cells. Obviously, nothing was found in it; or they would have mentioned it. Congrats on a very good path report! -Bob

Posts.Title: Need help with path report

Posts.Content: My lab does the ultra-sensitive PSA test, and anything below 0.06 is considered zero. I also had a PSA at 6 weeks, and it was < 0.06. I have had one every 3 months since then and they have all been < 0.06. My Uro said that it takes about 6 weeks for any PSA to work itself out of your system; that was why he had my first one at 6 weeks post-op. -Bob

Posts.Title: I'm going for my 90-day post-da Vinci PSA. How low should my score be?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tmack1 Can anyone shed light on the meaning of the "less than one high power field" used in both the 'margins' explanation and the extraprostatic extension explanation?? tmack1 I found this here:http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1502366 Extraprostatic Extension Because the prostate lacks a discrete capsule, the term “extraprostatic extension” has replaced “capsular penetration” to describe tumor that has extended out of the prostate into periprostatic soft tissue. In some cases, because of the desmoplastic response, it can be difficult to judge whether the tumor has extended out of the gland or is within the fibrous tissue of the prostate. This can be resolved by looking at the adjacent edge of the prostate on scanning magnification to see whether the normal rounded contour of the gland has been altered by a protuberance corresponding to extension of tumor into the periprostatic tissue. In palpable cancers (T2), extraprostatic extension preferentially occurs posteriorly and posterolaterally by perineural invasion. In transition zone cancers found in stage T1b and some T1c tumors, extraprostatic extension occurs anteriorly, usually by direct stromal invasion without prominent perineural invasion. Dr. Epstein designates cases in which only a few glands are seen outside the prostate as “focal” (less than one high-power field on no more than two sections), whereas cases with more extensive extraprostatic spread are designated “established extraprostatic extension.” Other methods of quantifying the extent of extraprostatic extension based on the depth of penetration, the width of penetration, or the length multiplied by the width do not correlate with progression. So, it sounds like your pathology report is saying it was not much of an extension. That means it IS good news! Hope that helps. Bob

Posts.Title: Surgical Path Report questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by WifeinWorry Well chemo is over, now its just HT again, switching to Lupron every 3 months.......its wait and see how it has mastered.....should we get bone scans etc again to see how well chemo/HT combo worked? Hello, WifeinWorry. If there is one thing I have learned in fighting this Beast, its the fact that there is a lot of waiting involved. I am convinced that our biggest enemy in this fight is the mental one. While we wait for results, our minds conjure up all kinds of horrible things. The good news for your husband is that the chemo is over, and he made it through it. I have not had to experience that myself, yet, and I hope I never do; but from what I have seen on this Forum it is not easy. He has achieved a big step getting through it. Enjoy that. Another thing I've learned in this Journey - appreciate any and all victories you can! Celebrate this victory, and wait as patiently as you can for the next steps. I will be praying for you both. -Bob

Posts.Title: Post Chemo

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Sorry to hear that news Dad. In my opinion you should consult an oncologist specializing in prostate cancer. A year after RALPH my PSA began climbing. At 0.17 I met with an oncologist and elected to go with salvage radiation. I had 33 rounds with zero side affects after almost 2 years. My Gleason was 7 (3+4) Good Luck Allen Thanks, Allen. The med-onc we consulted with does specialize in PCa, so I am pretty confident in her assessment. I just wanted to hear what others had to say who have been where I am now. As far as SRT side-effects, my biggest concern is aggravating incontinence. My surgeon cut very aggressively during my surgery, because he could see, once he got in there that the cancer had escaped. I have total ED, since he did not spare the nerves. After 3 years, I still have some very mild incontinence - I wear an ultralite pad every day just for the occasion dribble. Some of my reading indicated the SRT could make that worse. How about fatigue - did you experience any of that? That is another prominent SE I have read about with SRT. Thanks for your input! -Bob

Posts.Title: After 3 years, the Beast is back

Posts.Content: Well; it appears that the Beast is back, and I will soon have to seek other treatment. April was 3 years since my RALP. Until January, I had been undetectable - < 0.06. In January, and again in March, it was 0.08. In June, it was 0.11. I visited a medical oncologist last week and she said it does appear to be the beginnings of BCR. She wants me to get my next PSA in September, to see if they can get a better handle on velocity. She suggested SRT after I get the new PSA number, even though most of my numbers suggest it is not local. She said I had a 20-30% chance of still obtaining a cure, if it is local. As you can see by my stats; and acknowledged by the med-onc; the only thing that suggests local recurrence is the somewhat slow rise in the PSA. My Gleason score, stage, negative margins, and time to recurrence suggest that it is distant. While it would be great to still have a shot at a cure; the possibility of side-effects with the SRT does not thrill me, especially if it wouldn't do any good with a distant recurrence. Has anyone here faced similar stats? Did you go with the SRT, and did it work? I am still undecided. At least I have until September to make a decision. Do you think it would be helpful to talk to a rad-onc, and get their thoughts? My first inclination is that a rad-onc would just say to get the SRT. Thanks, Bob

Posts.Content: Yeah; that is mostly my feeling; any chance is better than none. The med-onc we talked to is the head of Advanced Urological Cancer at the University of Michigan Cancer Center. We narrowed the choice down to three: UofM, Cleveland Clinic, and Ohio State University. UofM seemd to have the best credentials. We were very happy with her and her staff. I just like to be as sure as possible; and I have always found very helpful information on this forum from those who have gone before me in this journey. Thanks for the advice. The med-onc did say that we were welcome to speak with the rad-onc at UofM; so I'm thinking I will take her up on that. -Bob
